Elizabeth Fay argues, in ways that again help place Wordsworth at the centre of contemporary debates on the role of ecology (and nature generally) in the politics of the person and the state, that Wordsworth’s poems perform the act of making their performance appear natural or purely descriptive. Much interest exists today about what is or isn’t ‘natural’ about persons, governments and everything in-between
Exploring New Ethics for Survival
